name: Magnum
language: No language but a software package
keyboard: Full-stroke 76 keys with function and arrows keys
ports: 2 x ROM cartridges, 2 x Serial, Parallel, Composite video, Expansion port
power: External power supply unit, Ni-Cad battery
description:
Like the HP-110 or the Sharp PC-5000, the Dulmont Magnum belongs to the first family of notebook computers with LCD screen (not yet back-lighted). Moreover, it was the first computer conceived and manufactured in Australia. It was also called Kookaburra (an Australian bird) for some export markets.

The Magnum was a PC-compatible system featuring an Intel 80186 processor, 96 KB of RAM, an 8 line LCD screen and several management software in ROM: word processor, spreadsheet, telecommunication, file manager, and appointment. Additional ROM software could be added thanks to two 128 KB cartridge slots.
A rechargeable Ni-Cad battery pack allowed ten to twelve hours of continuous use, and a lithium battery kept the content of the RAM memory when the system was turned off.
Due to various RAM/ROM configurations in the system, the drive letters assignation was specific to the Dulmont: drive A corresponded to the software in ROM, drives B and C, to each optional ROM expansion, D to the internal C-MOS RAM, E and F to the external floppy disc drives.
_______________________

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's new. It's the Hit-Bit" <br><br> "The computer according to Sony"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode!  If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then.  Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics.  Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font>       </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, OCT. 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Yannick Noah Tennis cartridge. The game is only called "Grand Slam Tennis" on the Emerson Arcadia 2001, but in France was marketed with the most famous french tennis player's name, Yannick Noah.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US DEALER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, parents interested in expanding their children's educational experience, turned to expensive encyclopedias. With the advent of the PET personal computer a new avenue of visual learning is now available for your youngsters for as low as $595....<br><br> ... Your youngster will think he's playing, you'll know he's learning with the remarkable PET... </font><br><br> At the time, parents often thought a personal computer could help their youngsters learning, but 80% of the home computers sold in the 80's was used only for playing. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Douglas Reedy</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>
